Assignment 9

Part One: Recipe Website

Create a small, one-page website to share your favorite recipe - it can be original or taken from your favorite food blog/recipe site. Establish a typographic hierarchy using different font sizes, styles and weights.

The page should include:

  1. A "navigation element" that uses positioning (the links don't need to lead anywhere.
  2. At least one image of the recipe.
  3. Recipe title, description, ingredients and instructions.

Please use:

  1. At least one `background-image` element in your css.
  2. A custom web font.

Layout and styles are up to your discretion. Get creative; take a look at food blogs, dribbble or pinterest for design inspiration if you're feeling it.

Part Two: Portfolio Site Research

Research online portfolio sites. They can be of designers, photographers, illustrators, cake decorators, you name it. Take screenshots of the homepage and a project page of your favorites.

Choose one site to mockup how you would structure the home page and subpage in html. Either sketch directly on the screenshots (printed or on the computer) or draw out the elements on paper.

Upload to Dropbox

Create a week_09 folder in your Dropbox. Create a subfolder for the recipe site and one for the Portfolio Site research - upload screenshots and site files to one and your portfolio research and sketches to the other.

Assignment 8

Create a new html document with at least three elements on the page. Assign each one a different position value to demonstrate how they work. Get creative with your styles and content.

Upload your files and a screenshot of your page to a week_08 folder in your Dropbox.

Assignment 6

Part One: Add pages to your New Yorker site

Replicate a sub-page from the New Yorker.

Replicate a article page from the New Yorker.

Put your article file in a folder.

See these mockups for reference:

Sub Page

Article Page

Use dummy text and whatever images you wish.

Part Two: Link your pages together

Link from the home page to an article.

Link from the home page to a sub-page.

Link from a sub-page to an article.

Create a new folder, take screenshots, upload the screenshots and your files to Dropbox.

Part Three: Prep for the next class

Sign up for Amazon Web Services

Once you're signed up, buy a domain name through Amazon Web Services Route 53

Class presentation:

  • PDF

Assignment 5: Add visual styles to your New Yorker site

Go to Google Fonts and find any sans-serif font that is similar to the one used in the New Yorker.

Add visual styles to your New Yorker home page. Use the correct fonts, text sizes and weights, colors and other styles to make your site match the design of the New Yorker.

Add your own hover styles to the links on the site.

Take a screenshot(s) of your finished site. Record a gif using Licecap of your hover state.

Make a folder called “week_05”, upload. your site files and screenshots.

Start thinking of a domain name want to use later on.

Assignment 4: Finish Coding the New Yorker site

Finish building out the New Yorker page using HTML and CSS.

Work on adding the remaining content, achieving the correct layout and spacing.

Feel free to use Lorem Ipsum of your choice as the content.

Take a screenshot of your site.

Create a folder called "week_04" in Dropbox.

Upload your site files and screenshot to Dropbox.

We'll keep adding to this in next week's class to work on the Typography, adding new pages and interactions.

Assignment 3: Sketching Code

Download the project files.

Print out "New Yorker Page.png" or sketch it out on paper (grid or dot paper works well for this if you have some).

Make notes on the paper about what HTML elements and css styles you’ll need to code the page.

In your Dropbox folder, create a folder called "week_02", move the files from last week's assignment there.

Create another folder named "week_03". Take a photo of your notes and upload them to this folder.

We'll start coding this together next week. Please bring your printout or notes to class and be prepared with any questions.

Assignment 2: Adding more elements and styles

In the file we worked on in class, complete the following tasks:

  1. Change the background-color of the `body`
  2. Add a border, background-color, and padding to the `div`
  3. Change the font of both the `h1` and the `p` element
  4. Add an element we did not go over in class, use W3Schools as a reference

When you've completed those tasks, take a screenshot of your page. Upload the screenshot and your files to your Dropbox folder.

Week 1 September 6, 2017

In Class: Introductions & Overview

  1. Introductions
  2. Review Syllabus
  3. Set Up Dropbox
  4. Install Text Editor

Assignment: Set Up

  1. Create a folder in the shared Dropbox folder that corresponds with your section. It should follow this naming format: "LastName_FirstName", ex: `Silva_Cristina`.
    • Section 01: Wednesday, 5:45pm
    • Section 02: Wednesday, 7:00pm
    • Section 05: Wednesday, 4:00pm
  2. Download and install your text editor of choice. Sublime Text or Atom are good options.
  3. Fill out this survey to help me teach y'all better.
